# List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Hurricane_Isabel_from_ISS.jpg/300px-
Hurricane_Isabel_from_ISS.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hurricane_Isabel_from_ISS.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hurricane_Isabel_from_ISS.jpg "Enlarge")

[Hurricane Isabel](/wiki/Hurricane_Isabel "Hurricane Isabel"), as seen from
the [International Space Station](/wiki/International_Space_Station
"International Space Station") in September 2003.

A total of 33 recorded [tropical cyclones](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone "Tropical
cyclone") have reached Category 5 strength on the [Saffir–Simpson hurricane
wind scale](/wiki/Saffir%E2%80%93Simpson_hurricane_wind_scale "Saffir–Simpson
hurricane wind scale") in the [Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic
Ocean") north of the [equator](/wiki/Equator "Equator"), the [Caribbean
Sea](/wiki/Caribbean_Sea "Caribbean Sea"), and the [Gulf of
Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico"). Hurricanes of such intensity
occur once every three years in this region on average.

Only six times—in the [1932](/wiki/1932_Atlantic_hurricane_season "1932
Atlantic hurricane season"), [1933](/wiki/1933_Atlantic_hurricane_season "1933
Atlantic hurricane season"), [1961](/wiki/1961_Atlantic_hurricane_season "1961
Atlantic hurricane season"), [2005](/wiki/2005_Atlantic_hurricane_season "2005
Atlantic hurricane season"), [2007](/wiki/2007_Atlantic_hurricane_season "2007
Atlantic hurricane season"), and [2017](/wiki/2017_Atlantic_hurricane_season
"2017 Atlantic hurricane season") hurricane seasons—has more than one Category
5 recorded hurricane formed. Only in 2005 have more than two Category 5
hurricanes formed, and only in 2007 and 2017 did more than one make landfall
at Category 5 strength.[1]

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Category_5_Atlantic_hurricanes&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

[Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind
scale](/wiki/Saffir%E2%80%93Simpson_hurricane_wind_scale "Saffir–Simpson
hurricane wind scale")  
---  
TD | TS | C1 | C2 | C3 | C4 | C5  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Map_of_Atlantic_Category_Five_hurricanes.png/300px-
Map_of_Atlantic_Category_Five_hurricanes.png)](/wiki/File:Map_of_Atlantic_Category_Five_hurricanes.png)

[](/wiki/File:Map_of_Atlantic_Category_Five_hurricanes.png "Enlarge")

Tracks of all known Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes between 1851 and 2014

A Category 5 Atlantic hurricane is one that is considered by the United States
[National Hurricane Center](/wiki/National_Hurricane_Center "National
Hurricane Center") (NHC), to have had sustained wind speeds greater than 136
knots (157 mph; 252 km/h; 70 m/s) on the [Saffir–Simpson
scale](/wiki/Saffir%E2%80%93Simpson_scale "Saffir–Simpson scale"). The NHC
considers sustained wind speeds to be those that occur over a one-minute
period at 10 metres (32.8 ft) above ground. These wind speeds are estimated by
using a blend of data from a variety of sources, which include observations
from nearby ships, reconnaissance aircraft, or automatic weather stations and
pictures from various satellites.

Between [1924](/wiki/1924_Atlantic_hurricane_season "1924 Atlantic hurricane
season") and [2017](/wiki/2017_Atlantic_hurricane_season "2017 Atlantic
hurricane season"), 33 hurricanes were recorded at Category 5 strength. No
Category 5 hurricanes were observed officially before 1924. It can be presumed
that earlier storms reached Category 5 strength over open waters, but the
strongest winds were not measured. The [anemometer](/wiki/Anemometer
"Anemometer"), a device used for measuring wind speed, was invented in 1846.
However, during major hurricane strikes the instruments as a whole were often
blown away, leaving the hurricane's peak intensity unrecorded. For example, as
the [Great Beaufort Hurricane](/wiki/Great_Beaufort_Hurricane "Great Beaufort
Hurricane") of 1879 struck North Carolina, the anemometer cups were blown away
when indicating 138 mph (222 km/h).[2]

A [reanalysis](/wiki/Atlantic_hurricane_reanalysis "Atlantic hurricane
reanalysis") of weather data is ongoing by researchers who may upgrade or
downgrade other Atlantic hurricanes currently listed at Categories 4 and 5.[3]
For example, the [1825 Santa Ana hurricane](/wiki/1825_Santa_Ana_hurricane
"1825 Santa Ana hurricane") is suspected to have reached Category 5
strength.[4] Furthermore, [paleotempestological](/wiki/Paleotempestology
"Paleotempestology") research aims to identify past major hurricanes by
comparing sedimentary evidence of recent and past hurricane strikes. For
example, a "giant hurricane" significantly more powerful than [Hurricane
Hattie](/wiki/Hurricane_Hattie "Hurricane Hattie") (Category 5) has been
identified in [Belizean](/wiki/Belize "Belize") sediment, having struck the
region sometime [before 1500](/wiki/Pre-1600_Atlantic_hurricane_seasons
"Pre-1600 Atlantic hurricane seasons").[5]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/1924_Atlantic_hurricane_10_track.png/220px-1924_Atlantic_hurricane_10_track.png)](/wiki/File:1924_Atlantic_hurricane_10_track.png)

[](/wiki/File:1924_Atlantic_hurricane_10_track.png "Enlarge")

An [October Category 5](/wiki/1924_Cuba_hurricane "1924 Cuba hurricane") that
hit Cuba in [1924](/wiki/1924_Atlantic_hurricane_season "1924 Atlantic
hurricane season")

Officially, the decade with the most Category 5 hurricanes is 2000–2009, with
eight Category 5 hurricanes having occurred: Isabel (2003), Ivan (2004), Emily
(2005), Katrina (2005), Rita (2005), Wilma (2005), Dean (2007), and Felix
(2007). The previous decades with the most Category 5 hurricanes were the
1930s and 1960s, with six occurring between 1930 and 1939 (before naming
began).[1]

Nine Atlantic hurricanes—[Camille](/wiki/Hurricane_Camille "Hurricane
Camille"), [Allen](/wiki/Hurricane_Allen "Hurricane Allen"),
[Andrew](/wiki/Hurricane_Andrew "Hurricane Andrew"),
[Isabel](/wiki/Hurricane_Isabel "Hurricane Isabel"),
[Ivan](/wiki/Hurricane_Ivan "Hurricane Ivan"), [Dean](/wiki/Hurricane_Dean
"Hurricane Dean"), [Felix](/wiki/Hurricane_Felix "Hurricane Felix"),
[Irma](/wiki/Hurricane_Irma "Hurricane Irma") and
[Maria](/wiki/Hurricane_Maria "Hurricane Maria")—reached Category 5 intensity
on more than one occasion; that is, by reaching Category 5 intensity,
weakening to a Category 4 or lower, and then becoming a Category 5 again. Such
hurricanes have their dates shown together. Camille, Andrew, Dean, Felix,
Irma, and Maria each attained Category 5 status twice during their lifespans.
Allen, Isabel, and Ivan reached Category 5 intensity on three separate
occasions. However, no Atlantic hurricane has reached Category 5 intensity
more than three times during its lifespan. The November 1932 Cuba hurricane
holds the record for most time spent as a Category 5 (although it took place
before satellite or aircraft reconnaissance, so this record may be somewhat
suspect). Irma holds the record for longest continuous span as a Category 5
storm in the satellite era.[1][6]

Thirty-three Category 5s have been recorded in the [Atlantic
basin](/wiki/Atlantic_basin "Atlantic basin") since 1851, when records began.
Only one Category 5 has been recorded in July, eight in August, nineteen in
September, five in October, and one in November. There have been no officially
recorded June or off-season Category 5 hurricanes.[1]

The July and August Category 5s reached their high intensities in both the
[Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") and the [Caribbean
Sea](/wiki/Caribbean_Sea "Caribbean Sea"). These are the areas most favorable
for tropical cyclone development in those months.[1][7]

September sees the most Category 5 hurricanes. This coincides with the
climatological peak of the Atlantic hurricane season, which occurs in early
September.[8] September Category 5s reached their strengths in any of the
[Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico"), [Caribbean
Sea](/wiki/Caribbean_Sea "Caribbean Sea"), and open Atlantic. These places are
where September tropical cyclones are likely to form.[7] Many of these
hurricanes are either [Cape Verde-type storms](/wiki/Cape_Verde_hurricane
"Cape Verde hurricane"), which develop their strength by having a great deal
of open water; or so-called Bahama busters, which intensify over the warm
[Loop Current](/wiki/Loop_Current "Loop Current") in the Gulf of Mexico.[9]

All six Category 5s in October and November reached their intensities in the
western Caribbean, a region that Atlantic hurricanes strongly gravitate toward
late in the season.[7] This is due to the climatology of the area, which
sometimes has a high-altitude [anticyclone](/wiki/Anticyclone "Anticyclone")
that promotes rapid intensification late in the season, as well as warm
waters.

##
Landfalls[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Category_5_Atlantic_hurricanes&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Landfalls")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Hurricane_camille.jpg/200px-
Hurricane_camille.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hurricane_camille.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hurricane_camille.jpg "Enlarge")

[Hurricane Camille](/wiki/Hurricane_Camille "Hurricane Camille"), a
landfalling Category 5

All Atlantic Category 5 hurricanes have made landfall at some location at
hurricane strength. Most Category 5 hurricanes in the Atlantic make landfall
because of their proximity to land in the Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico, where
the usual synoptic weather patterns carry them towards land, as opposed to the
westward, oceanic mean track of Eastern Pacific hurricanes.[50] Sixteen of the
storms made landfall while at Category 5 intensity;[1] 2007 and 2017 are the
only years in which two storms made landfall at this intensity.[1]

Many of these systems made landfall shortly after weakening from a Category 5.
This weakening can be caused by dry air near land, shallower waters due to
[shelving](/wiki/Continental_shelf "Continental shelf"), interaction with
land, or cooler waters near shore.[35] In southern Florida, the return period
for a Category 5 hurricane is roughly once every 50 years.[51]
